The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suskin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddag continuing every other week to Suskin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8.30 a.m. in time for Express to Switzerland, Paris and London, Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9.30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer.

div.head: Important Announcement.
div.p: Steam Ploughing, Cultivating, Levelling and Grading.

Messrs. K. & H. McLAREN, Manufacturers of Steam Ploughing Machinery. Midland Engine Works, Leeds, now beg to annoince to their friends in Egypt, that Mr. Henry McLaren, one of their principa's will be in Egypt for the month of March, 1906. He will be glad to make appointments with ay interested parties to show the our team plough tackle at work in Egypt, and will visit and inspect and lands on which it may be inteded to work steam ploughs, and give most favourable prices for suitable Machinery

He will also show them our new Patiens Gasobeah, or levelling scoop, at work, which is the most improved method of handling large quantities of sand or soil for levelling purposes which has yet been put upon the market.
Landed Proprieters, Agriculturists, and Contractors, are requested to communicate with Mr. McLAREN at Shepheard's Hotel, Cairo after March 1st, 1906. 27251-31.3.906

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. div.head: Sudan Land Problem.
div.p: The present feeling of discontent in which Sudan capitalists indulge does not seem to us to be justified either bby the present state of things or by the course which the Government has adopted in settling the all-absorbing problem of land (says the "Sudan Times"). Those of them that acted in sheer opposition to the Government's explicit orders have only their over-sanguiness to thank. In allowing their claims the authorities will be acting against all acknowledged ruled of government. Those claims cannot be entertained for a moment. They are based on sidovedience for Gocernment orders which forbade any purchases after a certain date. Nobody can expect the Government to endorse contravention of its orders, especially in the present case.
The fact that some sales have been antedates does not, we presume, help the claimants and it, we fear, leaves them open to some unpleasant experiences.

On the other hand we need hardly point out the advantages of a policy of consistency in this question. The law should be one for all. This is more easily said than done, but steps should be taken to apply it in every case at issue. To protect the natives and curb the speculative mania of the foreigner are very desirable objects, but they are only so when the law dealing with them is equally applied to the whole category.
The dark rumours about Gezirah do not strike us as being true and in the absence of any official information it would be better to await the decisions of the settlement officers.

div.head: Popular University.
div.p: Dr. A. Rieti will give a lecture at the University at 9.15 this evening ou "Evolution."

div.head: Sudan Irrigation.
div.p: A credit of L.E. 150,000 has been granted by the Council of Ministers for the Sudan Irri­gation Service.
Alhambra.
The revue Eh I Comment l is drawing crowded houses nightly. A matinée performance will be given to-morrow afternoon.
Murder of Greeks.
It is reported from El Fashn that a gang of robbers broke into the house of a Greek two days ago and killed his mother and wife.
Coal Imports.
The imports of coal from January 1 to April 26 amounted 418,090 tons, compared to 250,040 tons during the same period last year.
The Zeitoun Express.
The" trials of the express for the Pont Limon-Zeitoun line have given excellent re­sults. The distance was traversed in seven minutes.
Gabbarl's New Bridge.
The Egyptian Railway Administration has got down to the foundations for the new bridge at Gabbari. It has been discovered that an old quarry formerly existed at the site.
The Upper Nile.
Lewa Henry Pacha, Sir R. Slatin Pacha, and Kaimakam Amery Bey have left Khar­toum for Gondokoro to take possession of the posts evacuated by the Congolese troops. Menagerie at Alexandria. . \
Masserini's menagerie, which is not unknown to Alexandrians, has again arrived in this town and will shortly open on a plot of ground behind the General Post Office.
Provincial Fires.

Our provincial correspondents report that fires in the villages have been frequent of late. In most cases the cause has been the disastrous habit the native has of storing straw and other inflammable material on the roof of his house.
Union Artistique Francaite.

The members of the Union are giving a musical and dramatic entertainment at their clubrooms to-night, commencing at 9.15. The programme includes two one-act comedies, La Recommendation and Le Misanthrope et 1' Auvergnat.
Saint Vincent de Paul.

The annual charity fete in aid of the Societe de St Vincent da Paul will be held to-morrow in the church of the Jesuit Fathers, Alexan­dria. Low mass will be celebrated at 10.30 a.m., the sermon being given by Rev. Father A. Gartiser. Mme. Pierre Girard and Mme. Gescher will undertake the collection.

div.head: Egypt and Turkey
div.p: GRAVE SITUATION.
INCREASE OF BRITISH GARRISON.
London, April 27.

The "Times" in an article regrets to Bay that the situation which the Sultan has wan­tonly created has become graver. It mentions a report that the Turks have removed the beacons on the frontier at El Arish and adds that it is impossible that we should long continue to tolerate sots of this kind directly encouraging unrest, which certain intriguers in Cairo, some of whom in a high position, are foolishly endeavouring to provoke. (Rustar)
London, April 27.

Besides the three companies of Inniskilling Fusiliers coming from Crete, a battalion o infantry is about to be sent from Malta .to Egypt. Another battalion at Malta is under orders to hold itself in readiness to proceed at very short notice. Arrangements are being made for the transport of cavalry and artillery from the United Kingdom. (Reuter)

div.head: Berlin Official Opinion.
div.p: London, Saturday.

The "Daily Telegraph's" Berlin Correspon­dent says that in Berlin official circles it is not believed that the Sultan will allow the difference with the Egyptian Government to develop into a serious quarrel, especially as the Anglo-Egyptian view seems to have right on its side. The reinforcements which are to be sept to Egypt are regarded' as having the character of strong pressure on decisions at Constantinople.
The suggestions that Germany is sup­porting the Sultan in his attitude towards the British Government are characterised as spiteful phantasy.

A contemporary states that a German Mission, which recently made its appearance at El Arish, the frontier town of Egypt on the Syrian coast, has been requested to withdraw is soon as possible by the Governor. This members of the Mission complied with the request.
Another German Mission is stated to have made its appearance in Syria. Antiquities are its ostensible object.
Major-General L V. Swaine, writes to the "Times":

The occupation by the Turks of Tabah and the incident on the Persian frontier is clearly a game which appeals to the ingenuity of Turkish commanders. When I was Military Attaché n Constantinople 25 years ago Dervish Pacha's name cropped up in connexion with the occupation of Dulcigno. I inquired of one of my colleagues what the antecedents of this Pacha rare. He replied, "Dervish Pacha est tres fort sur des questions de frontetres," and then went in to tell me that some yean back be had received a command near the Persian frontier shortly after that portion had received a rectification, and one of his first acts was to move ;he frontier stones several kilometers back into Persian territory.

div.head: Important New Issue.
div.p: The Commercial, Industrial and
LAND CO. OF EGYPT.

In another column of to-day's issue we publish the prospectus of an important new flotation, styled the "Commercial, Industrial and Land Company of Egypt, Limited." The business of Messrs. R. Kuster & Co., Edgar Kirby & Co., and Murdoch and Templeton, which will be taken over from the Vendor Company, are too well known in Egypt as solid and flourishing undertakings to need any commendation from ns. They are long established concerns, which should be all capable of great extension, when under the direction of a powerful combination. Besides these options there are the monopoly of the Government concession of the supply of electric light to M&o8ourah, and an excellent building site at Rofish. The company ought to be favourably received by the public.

div.head: Lord Cromer's Report
div.p: The "Times" discusses Lord Cromer's scheme of reform and says from its statesmanlike breadth of view and rigid impartiality it deserves the attentive and sympathetic examination of all well-wishers of Egypt. (Reuter)
The French translation of Lord Cromer's report is complete, or all but complete. The translator is M. Agoub Kemeid, attached to the Ministry of Public Works.

div.head: The Plague
div.p: Yesterday's plague bulletin records five fresh cases (one fatal) and four deaths in hospital at Deshna, and five oases and six deaths in the Samalout district.

div.head: The Tacoma at Alexandria.
div.p: The American cruiser Tacoma, which has been assisting the drydock Devey, arrived at Alexandria this morning and exchanged the usual salutes with Fort Saleh.

div.head: PERSONAL AND Social
div.p: The Vizier of Ali Ibn Dinar, Sultan of Darfour, has recently been visiting Cairo. He visited the Citadel and purchased a quantity of saddles and other Articles from the stores there.
Lieut-Col. A. M. Man tell, Commanding Royal Engineer in Egypt, came down to Alex­andria from Cairo on duty to-day.
Mr. R H. A. Stern, of the Ministry of Finance, has been transferred from the Mines Department to the Customs Administration, Alexandria.

Mr. Smedley Norton, the well-known travel­ler and author, who was so prominent in defending M. de Lesseps at the time when the reputation and fame of the famous engineer was the subject for many bitter attacks in the European Press, is at present on a visit to Alexandria.

Mr. Norton is perhaps best known as the author of the world-known song "Just a little ray of sunshine," which speedily stamped him as a writer of catchy songs and ballads. The two best-known pieces in his Bramcote Ballads are "Sergeant, call the Roll" and "The Roll of Fame," both contributions to the imperialistic literature called forth by the South African war. Mr. Smedley Norton saw active service in the Zula war under Lord Chelmsford and retains much of the vigour and enthusiasm of his youth, a foot which still finds expression in his writings.
Professor Flinders Petrie will begin a course of lectures on "Recent Discoveries in Egypt" or May 0 at University College, London.

div.head: Notes from Port Said.
div.p: Thursday, 26
Arrival of Turkish Transports.

The Turkish transport Bahr-el-Gedid arrived from Constantinople, with over 500 troops for the reinforcement of Feizi Pacha, in the Yemen. Large detachments are said also to have passed over the Damasous-Maan line, which may have given rise to the ramour the 5,000 troops having congregated near Akaba. The Yemen rebellion has now been going on for many months, the Turkish Go­vernment evidently being determined to see it through, in spite of their previous reverses and the rigours of the siege of Sana.
Passageof Troops

The S.S. Heliopolis, Kiew, Vanoouver, Errol, and Vesta, with 8,874 officers and men, passed through Port Said in one day. The British officers on board some of the ships testify to the excellent behaviour of the troops.
The Hawker Nuisance.

The shop-keepers in Port Said, some of whom, by the way, send oat salesmen them­selves, often complain about the competition carried on unfairly by unlicensed hawkers, who besiege passengers as they step ashore. Mach of the reputation which Port Said unfortunate­ly enjoys is due to the molestation and solicita­tions to which passengers are subjected. Often the latter themselves are very much to blame for this state of things, encouraging as they do these people, who approach them often with an assurance and impudence snob as they would never dare to show to residents. In all sea­ports and more especially tourist resorts "strangers are taken in." Everyone knows that there is one price for the passenger end an­other for the resident Shop-keepers who have stood out against this custom have sometimes to abandon the method of having a fixed price, as so accustomed are people to "bargaining and beating down" that it is found necessary to taka this habit into consideration. Both buyer and seller seem to follow the golden rale as modified by "David Ha ram" :—Do onto others as you know they would do onto yon, only do it first
TheAmerican Visit.

Preparations are being pushed forward for the passage of the enormous American floating dry dock through the Canal. The escort of the American auxiliary cruisers, Brutus, Caesar, Glacier and the cruiser Tacoma, have already commenced their passage to Suez.

The Americans were favourably impressed with their treatment in Port Said. They were especially interested in all appertaining to the 8uez Canal, a subject of great interest to them on amount of the structure of the Panama Canal. They are all enthusiasts on the extermi­nation of mosquitoes, coming fresh, some of them, from the results following their abolition at Havanah, New Orleans, and more recently in Panama, in the extermination of yellow fever and malaria.
Attack on Englishman.

It is not often that we have to chronicle any serious breach of the peace at Port Said. Two evenings ago, however, Mr. Nugent, the popular and respected chief engineer of Messrs. Wills and Co, was the victim of what can only be described as a dastardly, cowardly, and cold blooded attack while cycling to his home on the beach. Suddenly he was struck from behind by a stick ; although he attempted to defend himself was rendered senseless, his wounds requiring the attention of Dr. Coffey. The police have opened an enquiry, and it is to be hoped that the perpetrators of this unwarranted attack will be speedily brought to hook. We were pleased to hear that Mr. Nugent is progressing favourably, and that he will spon he his genial self again.
English Club.

The most recent attempt to amalgamate the two English clubs bids fair to be successful, a good representative committee having practically solved the question of a site by coming to terms with the proprietors of the new National Bank, in course of erection.

div.head: Notes from Suez.
div.p: Suez, Friday.
H. H. S. Nour el Bahr will sail from Suez to­morrow morning for Akaba with stores and despatches for H.M.S. Diana, which is still anchored at Faraon Island.
S. Monmouth sailed from Suez at 10 yesterday morning for China.

Last Tuesday Wednesday Suez experienced of the warmest khamseens, and temperature went up to 94° in the shade. Yesterday and to-day, however, owing to the strong notherly winds, it is somewhat cooler.

div.head: Cricket
div.p: CRICKET.
K.RR.C. v. Mr. SCOTT DALGLEISH'S XL

This match was played at Cairo yesterday, resulting, in a win for Mr. Soott-Dalgleir'a team. The Rifles won the toss and went in to bat and before lunch scored 59 for 4 wickets. Mr. Saunders and Capt. Biroham made nearly half the runs scored by their side, between them, and both played very good cricket Rome and Graves got most of the wickets. For the scratch XI. Capt. Rome was top scorer with a freely hit 72 which included twelve fours. Major Liddell, Capt. McMurdo, and Messrs. Goschen, Campbell and Franklin all played good free cricket and the regimental bowler was severely tried. Score and analysis:—

div.head: ARMY and Navy
div.p: The move of the 1st Battalion King's Own Scottish Borderers from Colchester to Egypt in relief of the 2nd Battalion Berks Regiment will take place in November next.

Captain A. J. B. Perceval, Northumberland Fusiliers, who recently took over the command of the Camel Corps of the Egyptian Army, has been connected with the "Fighting Fifth" for over fourteen years and he is the first on the captains' list fir promotion. He earned the D.3.O. in South Africa, and prior to that he went through the Khartoum Expedition under Kitchener.

Lieutenant R. B. F. Knox, 2nd Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers, has been selected for service with the King's African Rifles. He will be seconded in the Fusiliers. Mr. Knox served with the 1st Battalion in the South African campaign, 1901-02, and as a Railway Staff Officer (Queen's medal with three clasps, King's medal with two clasps).

The sensational accounts of the "Times" Correspondent concerning the effects which Lord Kitchener's regime has had in India and in the Indian Army are greatly discounted in military circles. Whilst, perhaps, all his reforms are not so successful as they deserve, it is re­cognised that the defense of India is in a much better position than it was some years ago.
The battleship Queen will be recommissioned at Devonport on the 8th May for another term of service with the Mediterranean Fleet. Captain Lewis Bayly will again command her.

A lot of bosh has been written in contrasting the merits of H.M.3. Powerful, flagship of the Australian Squadron, and H M S. Monmouth, with which the Admiralty was "trying to put off the Australians" instead of a better cruiser. Of course (he Powerful is more heavily armed than the Monmouth, but it must be remembered that the latter has very little protection apart from her steel deck and gun positions, whilst the county class is well pro­tected on the water line. The Powerful was intended as a fast cruiser to prey on an enemy's commerce, and she is a good bit of a white elephant in the Royal Navy.
London, April 20.
It is stated that the War Office is consider­ing the advisability of augmenting the number

of British troops in Egypt. Some time ago, it it may be recalled, the cavalry regiment and a battery of Field Artillery and a mountain battery were withdrawn from the force in Egypt and the Sudan, in conformity with Mr. Arnold-Forster's reforms." That heaven-born genius never touched anything that he did not spoil, and that was one of them. For certain reasons, which it would not be polite to go into, a strong force of troops is necessary in Egypt, and infantry without the support of cavalry and mobile artillery would be han­dicapped considerably if anything cropped up requiring their services. The Mounted Military Police have done splendidly since they replaced the cavalry, so far as police duties go, bat the entire withdrawal of the cavalry from Cairo was a step which was con­demned in military circles, and the advantage of a battery of 18-ponnders at the same place is too obvious to point out.

Captain Angus Cameron, Queen's Onu Ca­meron Highlanders, who has assumed the command of the Mongalla District, which is a second class one, has been serving with the Khedive's Army since Joly, 1899, when he joined it from his regiment, a battalion of which was then stationed in Egypt He saw some service in the Nile Expedition of that year, and in the operations which resulted in the final smash-up of the Khalifa and his followers. His services were recognised by a deserved mention in despatches and the medal with two clasps.

Not a little of the native troubles in Natal is due to the withdrawal of the Imperial troops from that colony. The 2nd Battalion Queen's Own Cameron Highlanders— a smart corps well known in Egypt—is now doing temporary duty in Natal.

It has been decided to maintain the South African garrison at the following strength dar­ing the current year : Cavalry, four regiments, 2,372 oi all ranks ; Artillery, two horse bat­teries, twelve field batteries, and two garrison companies, 2,742 ; Royal Engineers, seven companies, £43 ; Infantry, fourteen battalions; 12,437 ; Army Service Corps, 629 ; Army Ordnance Corps, 279; Army Veterinary Corps, 78 ; total of all arms, 19,983.
The cruiser Barham, Commander M. F. Sueter, which recently joined the Mediter­
ranean Fleet, has been detailed for duty at Constantinople, and up the Danube.

The following appointments have been made to the third class cruiser Perseus which is to be re-commissioned at Port Said for another turn of service on the East Indies station : Lien- tenants W. P. Koe (first). P. F. Willoughby (navigation officer), G. E. Camming, and C. L Fox ; Engineer Lieutenant W. A. P. Smith, Assistant Paymaster D. G. Hewlett, as Acting Paymaster ; Staff Surgeon C. J. E. Cook.

The Ordinary Shares are entitled to Dividends in priority to the Deferred Shares up to 7 per cent, in each year, and subject thereto to 60 per cent, of the balance of the profits available for distribution as dividend in each year, the Deferred Shares being entitled to the remainder of such balance.

In the event of the winding-up of the Company, the Capital paid up, or credited as paid up, on the Ordi­nary Shares will be repaid in priority to that paid up, or credited as paid up, on the Deferred Shares, and any surplus assets remaining after repayment of the Capital paid up, or credited as paid up, on all the Shares, will be divided as to 60 per cent, amongst the Ordinary Shares, and as to the remainder amongst the Deferred Shares.

PROSPECTUS.
Objects.

This Company has been formed for the purposes set forth in the Memorandum of Association, and particularly for the purpose of acquiring and developing industrial and other undertakings in Egypt and the Budaa, including the securing of Land Concessions, the development of Building Estates, and the con­tracting for Building and Engineering Work, and subsequently dealing therewith either by re-sale to Subsidiary Companies or otherwise.
Progress.

The progress of Egypt for many years past and the prosperity of the country under British control have been remarkable, proof of which is found in the various Reports and Official Publi­cations from time to time issued by or with the sanction of the Egyptian Government.

Extensive Government irrigation schemes have opened up new districts, railways are being extended and towns are being developed, whereby a growing demand for capital has been created for industrial concerns. of every descrip­tion. In this connection the "Egyptian Gazette" recently stated:—

"Many of the shops andadding businesses " can be amalgamated and controlled to the " advantage of all concerned. It is the duty of "finance to organise the matter, and to provide " the necessary capital. The Cairenes will "welcome such efforts, and the success of trading concerns, if properly capitalised and properly managed, will be colossal daring the " next decade."
Population.

The population has increased very rapidly owing to the constant stream of emigrants coming from all parts of Europe. The European population of Cairo has doubled itself within the last three years, and the total population of the city to-day is estimated to be one million. Rise in Land values.
As a natural consequence of this growth the value of land has during the past five years large­ly increased owing to the demand for building sites and agricultural areas.
An era of great prosperity having been thus inaugurated, there is an extensive field in Egypt for the profitable employment of capital under circumstances of an unusually advanta­geous character.
Options.
This Company has already obtained Options which enable it to acquire for development, should the Directors elect, the following busi­nesses and properties (more detailed particulars
of which, as set out in the Option Contracts or supplied by the Vendor Company, are enclosed with this Prospeotna).
The business of R. Kuster and Co., of Boulac and Zaptieh, in Cairo, and of Alex­andria, Engineers and Iron Merchants, and 6.136 Square metres of Freehold Land on which their Cairo premises are built.
The business of Edgar Kirby and Co.,Sanitary Engineers and Government Con­tractors, of Cairo, Alexandria and Mansourah, established for nineteen years.
The business of Murdoch and Templeton, Engineers and Contractors, of Mansourah, estab­lished in It 81.

The Monopoly under a Government Con­cession of the supply of Electric Light to the Town of Mansourah, with the necessary modern plant, which has been working since 1901 and the accounts of which show an increasing revenue. The owners of the concession are the above-named Murdoch and Templeton.
A Freehold Building Site of about three sores in extent in the Island of Rodah which is considered one of the most favoured positions for residential purposes.

The value of the Options consists not only in the businesses themselves, bat also in the freehold land included therein, and two of the Local Advisers of the Company have shown their confidence in the success of this undertak­ing by underwriting£50,000 of the present issue.

The trading profits of the above-mentioned businesses A. B, C, and D are not disclosed, inasmuch as the businesses are under option only ; bat the owners have disclosed in confi­dence the figures of their average net profits for the last seven years, and the Vendor Com­pany state that they have carefully checked the figures given with the books and the accounts of the various businesses and have found them to be correct. On the basis of these figures the Directors are of opinion that by amalgamation, central control, and consequent economy, the profit of 10 per cent, already earned by the businesses can be materially increased.
Vendor and Purchase Consideration.

The Vendor Company is the Westminster Industrial and Finance Developments Limited, of 3, Princes' Mansions, Victoria Street, in the City of Westmin ter, who by an agreement dated 20ih April, 1906, has agreed to sell the above-mentioned Options to this Company. The Vendor Company states that in obtaining these Options it his current considerable trouble and expense, including several journeys to Egypt ; but it asks for no remuneration for such trouble and expense and for such Options other than Shares in the Company, and the repayment of the expenses attending the pro motion and it has accordingly fixed the pur­chase price thereof at £14,COO, payable as to £10,000 in fully paid Ordinary Shares of this Company, and as to the balance of £4,000 in fully paid Deferred Shares of this Company.
Preliminary Expenses.

By the same agreement the Vendor Company has agreed to pay all the costs of the prelimi­nary Agreements and the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Company, and the registration thereof, and all stamp, fees and legal expenses, and generally all the preli­minary expenses whatsoever, inholding fees of Brokers and Solicitors, the ousts of printing, issuing and advertising this Prospectus, both in England and Egypt, and its translation for th9 latter purpose into both French and Ara- bio, and all printing, stamping, and allotment letters, in consideration whereof there is to be paid to it by this Company the sum of £9,000 in cash and £1,000 in fully paid Deferred shares of this Company.
The preliminary expenses (exclusive of the brokerage and underwriting commission here­inafter mentioned) are estimated at £9,000.
Underwriting Arrangements.

This^ Company has also entered into an agreement with the Vendor Company dated 26th April, 1906, whereby the former has agreed to pay the Vendor Company the Bum of £4,000 in oath, in consideration of the Vendor Company procuring subscriptions for 100,000 of the Ordinary Shares of this Company now offered for subscription, being at the rate of 4 per cent. thereon. Of this sum £2,500 is payable to the underwriters named in the underwriting agreements mentioned below.
This company will pay a brokerage of 3d. per share on all allotments made to the public in England on applications hearing brokers' stamps.

The amount fixed by the Articles of Asso­ciation as the minimum subscription on which the Directors may proceed to allotment is 10 per cent, of the Shares offered for subscription, bat the Directors will not proceed to allotment on less than £100,000.
Contracts.
The following are the material Contracts entered into:—

(1) Agreement made between R. Kuster & Co. and the Vendor Company contained in two letters both dated the 21st February, 1906, whereby R. Kuster & Co. gave to the Vendor Company an option until the 12th May, 1906, to purchase their business, in­cluding stock, book debts and plant for the sum of £85,018 E, and a further option to pn rebate the freehold of the land on which the Cairo premises stand for a period of twelve months at the price of £19,982 B, the total purchase price being thus £135,000 E, payable as to £60,000 in cash, and the balance in fully paid shares of this Com­pany. The stock is valued at £35,400 E, the book debts at £29.300 E, and the plant and machinery at £4 000 E, and the land at £49.982 E, a total of £118,682, so that £16,318 is payable for goodwill. (2) Agree­ment between Edgar Kirly & Co. Bud the Vendor Company contained in two letters both dated the 1st March, 1906, whereby Edgar Kirby & Go. gave to the Vendor Com­pany an option until the 12th May 1906, to purchase their business, inclusive of stock,

at the price of £31,000 sterling, payable as to £15,000 in cash and £16,00) in fully paid ah arcs of this Company, the stock being valu­ed at £15.000, so that £16,000 is payable for goodwill. (3) Agreement between Murdooh and Templeton and the Vendor Com­pany, contained in four several letters dated the 21st December, 1905, and the 9th, 15th and 26th February, 1906, whereby Murdooh and Templeton gave to the Vendor Com­pany an option until the 11th May, 1906, to purchase their business, inclusive of the shook, for the sum of £10,000 sterling, pay­able to £28.000 in cash and £2,000 in fully paid shares of the Company. Nothing is payable for goodwill. (4) Agreement between Murdoch & Templeton and the Vendor Company, contained in three several letters dated the 21st December, 1905, and 13th and 18th February, 190$, whereby Murdoch & Templeton gave to the Vendor Company an option until the 11th May, 1906, to pur­chase their electric light concession at Mansourah for the sum of £21,000 E in cash. (5) Agreement between L. Coseirelli, of Cairo, and the Vendor Company, contained in two letters dated the 22ad November,

and the 26th February, 1906, as to the purchase of the Rodah Island building site, for the pries of 30) piasters per square metre (6) Agreement dated the 10th March, 19 6, between the Vendor Company of the one part, and Gastoa John Weiss of the other part, whereby the said G. J. Weiss agreed to underwrite or obtain responsible applications for not less than 100,000 of the Ordinary Shares of this Company, to advertise the Prospectus of this Company in Egypt, and to perform other services in connection with its promotion, in consideration whereof the Vendor Com­pany agreed to pay to him the sum of £2,.r 00 in cash, £3,250 in fully paid Or­dinary Shares of this Company, and £1,000 in fully paid Deferred Shares of this Com­pany. (7) Letter 10th March, 1906, under which the said G. J. Weiss stipulates that his name shall appear on the Pros­pectus as broker to this Company. (8) Four several Underwriting Contracts, three where of are dated the 10vh March, 1906, and the other the 11th March, 1906, whereby Ciman Bey Cherif, A. W. Woldonberg & Co., Walter Ablitt and the said Gaston John Weiss each agreed to underwrite 25,000 Ordinary Shares of the above issue for a | commission of 2j per cent. in cash. (9) Agreement dated the 20.h day of April

being the above-mentioned Agree­ment for Sale, whereby the Vendor Com­pany agreed to transfer the aforesaid op­tions to this Company, and whereby the Vendor Company gave to this Company an option until the 15th May, 190$, to purchase the Rodah lriand building site for the 300 piastres per square metre. (10) Agreement dated the 20th day , of April, 1906, between this Company and the Vendor Company, being the^ above- mentioned agreement by the Vendor Com­pany to procure subscriptions for 100,000 Ordinary Shares of the Company.

Copies of the above-mentioned Contracts,, together with a print of the Memorandum ■ and Articles of Association of the Company (a copy of which Memorandum is printed on the book of this Pro3peotns and forms part thereof) may be seen at the Offices of the Solicitors of the Company, at any time daring business hours before the list of subscrip­tions is closed.
The Articles of Association contain the following provisions as to qualification and remuneration of the Directors :—
Directors' Qualifications.

The qualification of every Director is the holding of - shares of the Company of the nominal value of £250. except that prior to the date of the Statutory Meeting such qualification is the holding of one share.
Directors' Remuneration.

As remuneration for their services each of the Directors shall be paid out of the funds of the Company at the rate of £200 in each year, with an additional remuneration at the rate of £50 per annum for the Chairman. In addition, if in any year 7 per cent, is paid by way of dividend on the Ordinary shares, then 5 per cent of the net profits, after deducting therefrom the amount absorbed by' such per cent dividend, shall be paid to the Direc­tors by way of additional remuneration. Such remuneration by way of percentage shall bfa divided amongst the Directors in such pro­portions and manner as they shall from time to time agree, and in default of agreement- equally; and any Director holding far part of a year shall be entitled to a propor­tionate amount of each remuneration. Etch Director shall also paid or reimbursed his reasonable travelling expenses (including travelling to attend Board Meetings) whilst employed on the business of the Company. The Company in General Meeting may in­crease the amount of each remuneration either permanently or for a year or longer term.
The Directors have also power to grant to any Director required to go abroad or to render any other extraordinary services, such special remuneration for such services they think proper.

The Directors may from time to time appoint one or more of their body to be Ma­naging Director or Managing Directors of the Company, either for a fixed term or without any limitation as to the period for which he or they is or are to hold office, and may from time to time fix his or their remunera­tion. which may be by way of salary, or com­mission, or by participation in the profits, or by any or all of these modes.
A settlement and quotation on. the London and Cairo Stock Exchanges, and such other
Exchanging as the Directors may think desir­able, will be applied for in due course.

Application for Shares should be made on the form accompanying this Prospectus, and sent to the Bankers with a Cheque for the deposit drawn in favour of tin Bankers. Where no allolment is made the deposit will be re- j turned in full, and where the number of shares I allotted is less than that applied for, the J balance of the deposit will be applied towards the remaining payments, and the surplus, it any, resumed to the applicant. If default is made in payment of any instalment the instal­ments already paid will be liable to forfeiture.
Dated the 1st day of May, 1906.

div.head: Excelsior Hotels
div.p: Nos leoteurs tronveront, d'autre part, le prospectus demission de la Sooiete des Exoel- sior Hotels, dont nous lea avons dejk entre- tenus.

Le but principal de la nonvelle Sooiete eat 1'acquisition d'nn terrain sis an Caire, rond- poiut Soliman Pacha, vis-k-vis le Savoy-Hotel, pour y oonstruire et y exploiter un hotel; elle ponrra Ogalement aoheter, constrnire on exploi­ter d'antree etablissements similairee.

On verra dans le prospeotna d'Omisaion qne le premier Conseil d'Administration eet com­pose de S. E. Chakonr Pacha, president, et de MM. A. S. Constantinidi, Alexandre Lakah, Ch. J. Nioole et Hermann Spahlinger. Ce der­nier, qui eat fejk adminietrateur de la Sooiete de l'Industrie des Hotels, à GenOve, est an spOoialiste dont la competence sera precieuse.

Le terrain de la Sooiete est sitae dans le pins bean quartier du Cairo ; elle y oonstrnira an hotel monumental qoi ddpaasera en ele­gance, lnxe et confort tout ce qui exists dejk en Bgypte, et Ton pent prevoir que tant par roriginslite de sa conception que par le soin apporte à l'exeoution du programme que se sont tracds ses createurs, l'Excelsior Hotel sera sans rival.

Ajoutons qne nous oroyons savoir que la Societe ne s'en tiendra pas an seal Excelsior Hotel da Cairo, et qa'elle a de grands projets qui ne tarderont sans doute pas à Otre mis en execution tant en Egypte qu'k l'etranger.

Comme nous l'avons annonce, remission anra lien le 30 Avril anx guiohets de 1'Anglo Egyptian Bank, tant an Caire qa'k A'exandrie, et elle uasera ouverte que ce seal jour. Surles 37500 actions de L.E. 4 qui torment le Capital do la Sooiete, il en est offert 12500 à la sous- oriptiou publ-que, payables P.T. 50 à la sous oription, et P.T. 59 a la repartition. Une part de fondatear sera allouee à ohaque dix aotions ordiuaires.

div.head: Entreprise Commerciale et Industrielle
div.p: va lancer ioi dans le conrant de la semaioe prochaine, une grande eociete com- meroiale et industrielle sons le nom de "The Commercial, Industrial Land Co. of Egypt, Limited." Le but de cette sooiete, dont le capital est de £100,000 divise en 295,000 ac­tions ordinaires et 6,000 parts de fondatenrs, est l'acquisition de plnsieurs maisons anoiennes et bien connnes, parmi lesqaelles figurent R. div.head: Discoveries at Luxor
div.p: The excavations undertaken by Mr. Theodore Davis in the Theban valley of the Tombs of the Kings have again been successful in the disco­very of another remarkable sepulchre, that of Si-Ptah. It is near to the great grave chamber of Seti II, opposite the tomb of Baii and to that of Tansert, another member of Seti's family.

It is excavated upon the tomb hut is larger. Two flights of steps descend to the first entrance, then three corridors take you to a small chamber with a large columned hall beyond it. From the centre of this a slope leads to a lower level with two corridors which when excavated will probably he found to enter the chief sarcophagus chamber.
Some of the corridors have their inscriptions well preserved, including the king's portrait, bat those in the chambers have been rained by moisture.

Unfortunately robbers have broken ap the alabaster coffin and taken all valuables away, leaving, however, a number of hieratic ostraca and a few statuettes. It is to be hoped, how­ever, that more chambers on the lower level will be found intact and valuable antiquities be recovered from them.

div.head: British v. German Agents in Egypt
div.p: The "Manchester Guardian'' prints an ex­tract from a letter which recently appeared in the "Egyptian Gazette'' from a correspon­dent, urging that British firms, particularly in the Levant, should be represented by British agents. In commenting on this the journal asks, "What inducement would be given to a British agent to persist in forcing British goods and terms at a loss on an unwill­ing people 1 Is it not better—to take a ruth­lessly insular point of view—to min confiding foreigners over this hopeless task than oar own coutrymen 1 And, really, it is difficult to believe that tbe Germans can continue for decades to impoverish themselves by granting ruinous terms of payment Can it be possible j that the foreigner — German or whatever he I may be- sometimes understands the conditions of the market better than the Briton, and therefore makes a better agent 1"

Noos ne sommes, œrtes, pas enoore entrés dans la phase de la hausse, il est satisfaisant de oonstater des dis­positions de reprise juste à l'heure où, par snite des dffioultés inhérentes à une liquidation chargée, on pouvait, à bon droit, s'attendre à un nouveau tassement des ooun.

Une assemblée des actionnaires a bien eu lieu le 30 oourant, mais à titre extraordinaire pour délibérer sur des modifications aux statuts, ainsi qne sur une proposition d'augmentation du capital, et non pour s'occupa du bilan et du dividende.

Ce que sera oelui-ci, nul ne peut le savoir ; les administrateurs eux-mêmes seraient, cro- yons-noos, fort embarrassés pour le fixer à quatre mois d'intervalle de la date de l'assem. blée ordinaire qui aura à examiner le bilan et à statuer sur le ohiffre du dividende. Nous rappelons qne l'émission de la Sooiéti des Exoelsior Hotels aura lieu lundi proohaii 30 Avril, de 9 b. a.m. à midi et de 3 h. à 5 b pm.

Nous nous mettons à la disposition de oeui de nos olieota qui voudraient souscrire pa: notre entremise.

mais jnBqn'ioi il y a lotte et sa rAnsaite n'est que partielle. La filature, ponr sa part, se tient à l'Acart, oar elle vent voir venir les Avknements et en oela elle n'a pas tort, d'antant pins qne sea prAcAdents aohats ini assnrent du pain sur la planohe ponr lea premiers mois de la oompa- gne proohaine. En attendant, de 1'intArienr, on signale une tempAratnre favorable et une amAlioration seosible dans le dAveloppement de la plante. Qnant à la question de l'ean, les perspectives sont bonnes.

Le marohA du disponible est loin d'avoir AtA aotif et o'est en baisse de 3/4 de tallari, tant sor les Mit Afifi qne sur les provenanoes Hante Egypte qne la semaine se termine. Les Abassi et les Joancovioh qui sont reoherchAs et rares, snrtont les premiers, restent sans ohangement.

Ponr la semaine prochaine on prAvoit un ohiffre satisfaisant anssi, et oela snrtont k' oanse de la oroyanoe qne la baisse doit nons avoir vain de nonvelles affaires poor le dehors.
Liverpool a AtA plotdt faible poor les Agyptiens aveo ses ventes insignifiantes en disponib'e. Le prix ponrtant, aprks une baisse momentaDAe de 1/8, a fini par ravenir à son point de dApart.

Les AmArioains ont doncA lien à un pen pins d'affaires et la oote en gAnAral finit aveo 3 po:nts de hansse sur tonte la ligne.
La grkve en Angleteire semble AtrA AeartAe et la filature est tonjonrs sor le marchA poor les AmArioains. -

lies arrivages ont à peine atteint 6,000 ar- debs et, dans oes conditions, il n'est pas Aton- nant qne la demande ponr le disponible, qnel- qne petite qn'elle soit reetAe, ait AtA cause de la hansse des prix jarqn'k P.T. 74 ponr an joar. C'est anjonrd'hni senlement, qn'aprks un dAbnt pen enconrageant, one reprise subite a en lien, dAterminAe, oroyons- nons, par la hoilitA aveo laqnelle l'emprnnt raise a AtA absorbA, entikrement convert à Londres et plnsienrs fois à Paris.

D'antre part, notre situation finanoikre looale est bien Atablie ; les capitanx abondent, oom- me le dAmontra amplement la tavenr dont jonissent les nonvelles Amissions faites rAoem- ment en si grand nombre. Pent Atre, le revirament ayant AtA trop brnrqne, y anra til une reohnte, mais oelle-oi ne sera en tout oas qne momentanAe, oar le mois de mai s'annonce plein d'espArance.

Fant-il dire que les bonnes d'Europe ont montrA pea d'enthonsiasme oes junrs-ci.Cela se eon9 fit dans les oirroastances exceptionnelles de drainage de l'or dins tontes les oapitales d'Europe par snite des emprnnts russe, pros-1 sien, jsponais, des oa^&strophes da VAsave, de i Conrrikres, de 8an Franoisoo, sans parier des j liquidations laborienses de fin d'avril et de diverse8 complications politiqnes dont la ques­tion d'Akaba n'est qu'nn Apisode. Cet Atat de ohoses s'est tradnit par an Alkvement da tanx d'escompte à 3 1/2, et une baisse du oonsolidA anglais, de la rente franq rise et des valenrs en gAnAral. div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic

THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,
